name: 1,3-diethyl-5-methylbenzene
Reason: 1,3-diethyl-5-methylbenzene has a melting point that we can compare to the melting point of ethylbenzene, which has a melting point of -169.2°C. The basic unit for our comparison will be ethylbenzene. The structural modifications we need to consider are the presence of two additional phenyl rings. Phenyl groups, when connected to a benzene ring, tend to increase the melting point due to the enhancement of the crystalline structure and the increase in molecular weight. In the case of 1,3-diethyl-5-methylbenzene, we have two additional phenyl rings linked in a linear fashion, which would notably augment the melting point. Each additional phenyl group can be estimated to add approximately 100°C to the melting point due to increased pi-pi interactions, rigidity, and molecular weight.
